prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Accurate measurement of the radio flux is necessary for this observation. To minimize the spectral index error caused by the flux calibration, we request the single continuum mode with 4 spws with largest bandwidth. Since we observe the continuum source without any emission/absorption lines, the spectral resolution of the single continuum mode is enough to achieve our goal.

(1) Angular Resolution Although the sub-arcmin-scale structure of the target is point-like in the NVSS image at 1.4 GHz observed with VLA, it might have bright knots on killo-parsec scale like other blazar sources. Thus, high resolution (< 1") is necessary to extract the emission only from the core.
(2) Largest angular scales The source structure is expected to be simple, which is consisting of the predominant point-like radio core and possibly some faint point- or Gaussian-like knot features extended on arcsecond scales or larger. The image fidelity for faint features is not important in the proposed observation, since our aim is to measure the flux of the predominant and point-like radio core, we set the requested largest angular scale to the requested angular resolution.
(3) Justification of the short observing time related with the image fidelity Since our aim is to measure the flux of the dominant and point-like radio core, the snap-shot image is enough to achieve our goal.

As described in the Scientific Justification, our goal is measuring the radio flux at band 4 and band 7 of the radio core in the relativistic jet for determining the spectral index.
The minimum flux density of the radio core can be robustly estimated by assuming that the transition between optically-thin and optically-thick regimes locates at the highest frequency of previous VLBI data (dashed lines in Fig. 3 in the Scientific Justification). We require the image sensitivity to detect a signal of this minumum flux density with SNR of 20 in order to make the flux error due to thermal noises less significant than the flux calibration error (5% at bands 4; the proposer's guide).
We emphersize that the on-source time of 2-min estimated in OT can provide two times higher sensitivity than the requested one.
We also emphersize that all sources were detected sucessfully in Cycle 2 at Band 7, of which fluxes are estimated with the same way.
We confirmed that the spectral index determination with an accuracy of <0.15 can be achieved with the achieved sensitivity and spectral setting, by performing the Monte Carlo simulation assuming the flux calibration error in the proposer's guide (5% and 10 % in bands 4 and 7, respectively).

As described in the Scientific Justification, our goal is measuring the radio flux at band 4 and band 7 of the radio core in the relativistic jet for determining the spectral index.
The minimum flux density of the radio core can be robustly estimated by assuming that the transition between optically-thin and optically-thick regimes locates at the highest frequency of previous VLBI data (dashed lines in Fig. 3 in the Scientific Justification). We require the image sensitivity to detect a signal of this minumum flux density with SNR of 20 in order to make the flux error due to thermal noises less significant than the flux calibration error (5% at bands 4; the proposer's guide).
We emphersize that the on-source time of 2-min estimated in OT can provide two times higher sensitivity than the requested one.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose observations complementing ones approved in Cycle-2 with the highest priority, because 7 of 10 observations have not been conducted as of April 2015.
We have proposed to observe continuum spectrum of five extreme TeV blazars, which are unique probe to study enigmatic extragalactic background light (EBL), for the first time in mm/sub-mm regimes at two frequencies. The goal of this study is to investigate whether their relativistic jets are optically thin at mm wavelengths.
Our preparatory study with ALMA shows optically thin mm-spectrum in most normal blazars, contrary to the most accepted "one-zone SED model" predicting their relativistic jets are optically thick in mm regime. In addition, our study with VLBI does not favor it also for extreme TeV blazars.
If mm emission is optically thin in also extreme TeV blazars, it requires alternative models such as the structured jet model where both of high-energy emission and mm emission can come from the jet base. It will not only give a new picture of jets in blazars, but also affect studies on EBL based on SED models.
These sources are faint for other radio interferometers. Only ALMA can perform proposed observations.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00989S, Probing the inner-most region of the relativistic jet in extreme TeV blazars, Akiyama et al.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
Radio Astronomy Division, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
